newsitem.title: USA: Florida official says Prudential blocked probe.
newsitem.headline: Florida official says Prudential blocked probe.

text.p: Florida Insurance Commissioner Bill Nelson Monday charged Prudential Insurance Co. of America with obstructing a state probe into allegations the company misrepresented insurance policies as investments.

Nelson filed a formal administrative complaint alleging Prudential destroyed documents and ignored subpoenas in an investigation that began in April 1995 into allegations it "churned" customer accounts and misrepresented some policies. Churning is when brokers or agents trade a customer's account without permission to generate commissions.
He said the allegations stretched over at least 14 years and may involve more than 100,000 Florida policyholders.
The insurance commissioner said that unless the company provided the requested documents, it could face sanctions possibly including loss of its license to operate in Florida.

"By my order today, I'm putting the burden on Prudential to show why I should not impose the stiffest of fines or revoke or suspend its license to do business in Florida," Nelson said at a news conference in Tallahassee.

Florida is one of a handful of states that have not agreed to settle with the Newark, N.J.-based insurance company over charges that its agents throughout the 1980s misrepresented its products and sold insurance policies as investments.
The Florida officials said Prudential sold plain life insurance policies to elderly people by pitching them as tax-favoured investments or "inflation safety nets."
Nelson said he would give the "benefit of the doubt" to Arthur Ryan, the newly named chief executive of Prudential, in the hope the company would begin cooperating with Florida investigators.
Prudential said the company was open to talks with state officials.

Earlier this year, Prudential reached an agreement with 43 other states to pay a $30 million fine and set up a fund for policyholders who could prove their accounts were churned by the company's agents.

The company also has agreed in a separate $410 million class-action lawsuit that it would reimburse policyholders for similar practices. That case is still pending before a federal judge in New Jersey.
Prudential is the largest of a number of insurance companies to be charged with such practices nationwide in recent years.

Florida Attorney General Bob Butterworth said his department also was investigating the company. "We will pursue all the options available to us to ensure that all those who suffered are fairly compensated," Butterworth said.
"That will include the RICO act as well as civil theft," he said, referring to the state's Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organisation Act, which can lead to triple damages in certain cases.
Holding up a full-page advertisement in the Sunday edition of the New York Times, Butterworth said Prudential used consumer confidence in the company to deceive mostly elderly policyholders.

"When they talked about selling you 'a piece of the rock,' then they go ahead and hit you over the head with it," Butterworth said. "A piece of the rock" is Prudential's longstanding advertising theme line.
Butterworth also accused the firm of persuading policyholders to use the current value of their policies as collateral to purchase other products, allowing agents to earn additional commissions.
Nelson and Butterworth said they would file objections seeking to block the settlement in the New Jersey case. A hearing is set for Jan. 21.
"This settlement is a bad deal for policyholders. It does not begin to compensate Florida consumers whose pockets were picked," Nelson said.
